conclusion: Analyze the problem to find the change in electric potential energy when the ball reaches its highest point.

Given a uniform horizontal electric field, a small positively charged ball with mass m, initial velocity v0 from point O, moving along a straight line at angle θ to the opposite direction of the electric field, with forces acting: electric force (F_q) and gravity (mg).
The ball moves at angle θ to the opposite direction of the electric field, with the electric force along the field direction.
The highest point occurs when the vertical velocity component becomes zero.
Establish coordinate axes: x-axis horizontal (along the electric field), y-axis vertical (upward).
Initial velocity components are v0x = v0cos(θ) (horizontal) and v0y = v0sin(θ) (vertical).
The electric potential energy change is given by ΔU_e = -qE·d.
q is the charge of the ball, E is the electric field vector, d is the displacement vector from point O to the highest point.
Time to reach the highest point is t = v0y/g = v0sin(θ)/g.
Horizontal displacement during this time is dx = v0x * t = v0^2cos(θ)sin(θ)/g.
Since the electric field is horizontal, only the horizontal displacement contributes to the electric potential energy change: ΔU_e = -qE * dx.
For straight-line motion at angle θ, the components of acceleration must satisfy ay/ax = tan(θ).
ay = -g and ax = qE/m, therefore qE = -mg/tan(θ).
Substitute qE into ΔU_e formula: ΔU_e = mg/tan(θ) * v0^2cos(θ)sin(θ)/g.
Simplify to ΔU_e = m * cos(θ)sin(θ)/tan(θ) * v0^2.
Since tan(θ) = sin(θ)/cos(θ), ΔU_e = mcos^2(θ) * v0^2.
